summary: This is an FBI interview summary (302 form) with an interior designer, Couturier, who was approached by Jeffrey Epstein in 2010 to decorate his properties. Couturier describes his interactions with Epstein, his observations about Epstein's behavior and properties (including a room intended for 'girls'), and his eventual decision to decline the job. The document includes details about Epstein's assistants, employees, and residences.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The central figure discussed; Couturier describes being approached to decorate his homes, their meetings, Epstein's comments about having 'girls' visit, and his difficult personality.

persons.name: Couturier
persons.context: The individual being interviewed. He details his professional interactions with Jeffrey Epstein, his observations during visits to Epstein's properties, and his ultimate decision to back out of a design job due to discomfort.

persons.name: Ysabel Goldsmith
persons.context: Introduced Couturier to Jeffrey Epstein sometime between 1985-1988.

persons.name: Darren Indyke
persons.context: Listed by Couturier as one of Jeffrey Epstein's contacts/employees.

persons.name: Rich Kahn
persons.context: Listed by Couturier as one of Jeffrey Epstein's contacts/employees.

persons.name: Amy Fienne-Collins
persons.context: Mentioned as having written an article on child prostitution for Vanity Fair that met with resistance.

connections.description: Couturier was a potential interior designer for Epstein's properties. Their relationship was professional but strained, with Couturier finding Epstein difficult and ultimately refusing the job.
Goldsmith introduced Couturier to Epstein, indicating a social connection.

events.title: Couturier meets Epstein
events.description: Couturier is introduced to Jeffrey Epstein by Ysabel Goldsmith.

events.title: Initial design meeting
events.description: First meeting regarding decorating Epstein's USVI and Manhattan homes. Epstein's assistant handled the meeting as Epstein did not attend.

events.title: Trip to US Virgin Islands
events.description: Couturier, Epstein, and his assistants fly on Epstein's private plane to the USVI property. Epstein shows Couturier a room he wants decorated for 'his girls' and discusses their internet habits.

events.title: Epstein attempts to sue Couturier
events.description: Epstein tries to sue Couturier for the deposit after Couturier declines the job. Couturier later settles by returning $15,000.

events.title: FBI Interview
events.description: Couturier is interviewed by the FBI at his design studio, providing information about Jeffrey Epstein.

locations: 69 Mercer Street, New York, NY 10012 (Couturier's studio)
9 East 71st Street, Manhattan, NY (Epstein's New York residence)
keyFacts: Couturier observed a room in Epstein's USVI home that Epstein wanted decorated with four beds in a colorful palette for 'his girls,' noting they were interested in Facebook and MySpace.
In Epstein's Manhattan home, Couturier saw a massage room with photographs of nude young women, ages 15-20, which Epstein called 'artistic renditions.'
Couturier decided to decline a lucrative design job for Epstein due to discomfort with Epstein's behavior and comments, despite receiving a $50,000 deposit.
Epstein attempted to sue Couturier for the deposit after Couturier backed out, leading to a settlement where Couturier returned $15,000.
The document lists several of Epstein's contacts, including assistants, an attorney (Darren Indyke), and an accountant (Rich Kahn).
